I like this game a lot because I'm brain damaged and I create mods for single player. For your average player considering this game, I'd get it on a sale. It goes for pretty steep discounts during holiday and seasonal promotions. I would not pay the full $70 or $80. 

Many people consider NFS Heat to be the better game, but Heat and Unbound will be the last NFS releases we will see for while if not forever. If you catch the game at a 80% - 90% discount and it piques your interest, never hurts to try it out and see what you think.


Pros:
- Excellent graphics, audio, car models, etc. Arguably some of the best in the franchise
- Good customization, lots of licensed manufacturers and custom concept kits
- Expanded car list compared to previous game, every single car and most customization carries over from NFS Heat
- Driving feels good if you learn it. I like the sense of speed and how it doesn't rely on brake to drift unlike previous games
- Active multiplayer with a nice variety of event types
- Active modding scene. Multiple "overhaul" mods such as Project Unite, Unbound Remix, and Hard+ greatly supplement the game

Cons:
- Lackluster single player experience. Awkward progression and unremarkable story
- Car handling is tricky to master. Competitive play leans heavily on the "burst NOS" mechanic
- Not the best balance with car performance, with a few "meta" cars being behind a paywall
- Poor optimization just like NFS Heat, demanding on GPU and CPU resources. Low-end set ups will likely experience crashing
- No anti-cheat system for multiplayer, you might run into players using mods nefariously. This isn't super common and its easy to block other players
- Art direction isn't everyone's cup of tea. Animated driving effects can be disabled and many players mute the soundtrack
Spotify, YouTube, or Apple Music should really be listed in the system requirements. Still, it’s an amazing game — best to grab it on sale.

[b]I am here in defence of Need for Speed Unbound.[/b]
With 18.7 hours of this game with story almost finished. I feel pretty confident in saying that this game gets WAY more hate than it deserves. Unbound isn't perfect don't get me wrong, but it's a hell of a lot better than anyone gives it credit for.

[b]The Handling[/b]
The biggest criticism I keep seeing thrown around is the handling model, I think it's blown way out of proportion. Yeah, the drifting in my opinion can sometimes feel like a hit or miss. Earlier titles nailed that flowy, predictable drift zone and Unbound doesn't fully recapture it for me. The grip handling though? It feels great once you settle into it. The cars bite into corners, speed feels weighty, and there's momentum to everything that just works. People clowning the game for "feeling too arcadey" are missing the point entirely. This is an arcade racing game, the controls are meant to feel more exaggerated, it's meant to be loud, it's meant to be stylish! And Unbound's handling suits that vibe.

[b]Art Style[/b]
I'm one of those people that initially hated the graffiti style effects and cel-shading when the game was revealed. It just looked cheap and gimmicky. Then I started playing it and actually warmed up to it. Don't get me wrong the character art style still doesn't do much for me, but the effects around the cars? Burst nitrous trails, cel-shaded drift sparks and the stylized air time effects... they look absolutely FANTASTIC in motion. There's an energy to them that elevates big moments, and the more I played the more I realised they're one of the game's best additions. Honestly Criterion should double down on their concepts for the next games and stop playing it safe for each instalment. If you're going weird and stylish, commit to the idea, don't half a$$ it. 

[b]Progression and Economy[/b]
I bought the Ultimate Edition on sale for £11.24, so I started with a handful of cars which definitely softened the early grind. But even then the progression felt fair. Upgrades feel meaningful, especially when you bump the cars into the next grade. If you've got a favourite ride and want to take it all the way to the end, Unbound lets you do that, and that's something that previous titles messed up (Heat managed to almost do this but it still felt more limited than in this game. I would go further into it but I wanna stick to talking about Unbound).

I heard a handful of people talking about how they find the grinding too slow, and sure I don't entirely disagree. But NFS 2015 showered you in money, and everyone hated that too. I feel as though this has always been a difficult balancing act for each game.

[b]Cops (They're actually fun again!)[/b]
Need for Speed Heat had some great police chases but also made me terrified to even start one. Unbound fixes that. Challenging enough to feel exciting, but not too overpowered that you avoid them entirely. Different police tiers behave differently, from my experience car classes seem to influence how intense a chase gets, and the damage threshold is much kinder than Heat. If you keep calm and learn how to outsmart them instead of driving headfirst into every bus and lamppost, the chases are an absolute rush! It's honestly a shame some players aren't experiencing that side of the game with positivity. 

[b]Story and Characters[/b]
I can't defend this part, it's pretty bad. Not unplayably bad, but the writing feels like a group of out of touch board members trying to imitate "what the kids are saying these days." It's cringey, forced and shallow. Our protagonist also likes to sound and act like an idiot. You’re telling me that after witnessing one of your closer friends (Yaz) almost ruin your mentor’s career and steal the car you both worked on, my character is just supposed to forgive her like nothing happened? Absolutely not, I would have left that snake in the streets after winning the Countach back.

Right... where was I? Oh yeah. Older black box era NFS games understood how to keep things short, grounded and serious. Unbound's story feels like it's constantly trying too hard to be cool.

[b]Miscellaneous[/b]
The in-game soundtrack honestly sucked. I turned the entire music off for the game and played my own DnB spotify mix instead. It honestly made the game feel WAY better than whatever Unbound was trying to push. However, the sound effects are phenomenal. The wooshing noises going past cars, the audible horns as you race in the oncoming traffic lanes, nitrous boosts and car engines are an absolute bliss to listen to.

I stayed away from online because I have no interest in being paired with players that constantly try to ram you off the street. It's just not the way I play racing games so if you're looking for an insightful review of that I recommend checking other reviews and see what they say. 

[b]So Why All the Hate?[/b]
Some of the criticisms are completely fair. The story is cringe, characters are weak, drift handling (in my experience) lacks consistency and the economy can feel slow for some players. However the other complaints feel like people projecting. Complaints about handling because they wanted a sim when I believe NFS at it's core has always been more arcade focused, hating the art style without giving it a fair chance and the grinding aspect of these games will always be complained about whether it's too easy to gain money or too long to grind for it.

[b]Final Thoughts[/b]
Unbound does more right that it does wrong. Under all the graffiti and flair, there's actually a surprising amount of mechanical depth too. Car builds meaningfully change how your car handles, nitrous types serve different purposes, and the day/night risk vs reward cycle forces actual decision making instead of mindlessly driving to events and grinding for money. There's more room for experimentation and mastery here than people give it credit for. Yeah the story is bad and soundtrack isn't great, but the core of the game? It's way better than what other players lead you to believe. A lot of the hate feels misguided, exaggerated or just bitter.

If you want a lively arcade racer with personality, Unbound is absolutely worth your time.

Need for Speed Unbound is definitely a bold take on the series, and honestly, it works better than I expected. The stylized effects — the graffiti-like bursts, exaggerated smoke, all that flair — give the game a distinct personality without making it feel like a cartoon. The only downside is that the stylized visual effects may not be everyone’s taste. Sometimes they get a bit too flashy in tight races, making it harder to focus. But once you get used to them, they add a fun flavor rather than a distraction.

All in all, Unbound is a refreshing and confident step forward — stylish, fast, and full of personality.

Need for Speed: Unbound – The Good, The Dumb, and The “Why Is This Here?”

Let’s cut the crap — Need for Speed: Unbound isn’t top-tier NFS. It’s not hitting Most Wanted, Underground 2, or even Heat levels. But it’s not trash either — it’s just confused.

First off, that cartoony smoke, wings, and anime nonsense? Yeah, it’s stupid. Looks like someone lost a bet with Fortnite. Thankfully, you can turn most of it off. Do that, and the game suddenly feels like Need for Speed again instead of a youth-marketing experiment.

The characters? Meh. They talk like rejected influencers reading their own comment sections. You won’t care, but you won’t hate them enough to quit either.

The story’s corny — betrayal, clout, and “we’re taking back the streets” written by someone who’s never actually been on one. But once you’re past the cutscenes, the driving’s where it finds its footing. Cars handle well, the city looks great, and the chases actually get your heart rate up. Customization’s deep too — you can build something that feels yours.

So yeah, Unbound isn’t one of the greats, but it’s not a joke either. Turn off the cartoon crap, ignore the wannabe influencers, and what’s left is a solid — if confused — racer that’s worth picking up when it’s on sale.

Not sure where all the hate for this game ever came from but it's a solid entry from the NFS team... At least now after a few years since release, the devs receiving player feedback and rolling out updates over that time, this game has really become quite a joy.

Online mode is where I feel this game shines. The devs have truly perfected the online experience. I have yet to play "PVP" or "Lockdown" but the fact that we have dedicated modes for such is already a good sign. What I can speak to is how well integrated the online events are in conjunction wit the open world experience.

You aren't immediately harassed by police and can mind your own business, but you can get in a chase anytime you want by getting in a collision with a cop car. You can meet up for rounds of "Link Up" for a chaotically fun time (think of Forza's Forzathon Live events). Or you can start a race from a "Meet Up" location that gets sent out to all the other players in your session (lobbies of 16, races typically cap at 8)
so the chance for some old fashion grudge racing is still alive and well, even in the laid back online open world layout we have here.

If you are looking for a good modern NFS, you should also be looking at HEAT. UNBOUND is just a side-grade to HEAT, where both of them do things better/worse than the other.

Overall, this game isn’t worth for the SP. The boring campaign progression, weird difficulty wall, stingy payouts and lack of any endgame activity isn’t worth the experience. However, if you are looking for the MP, the story is different and it’s worth the check. The added mechanic of bust NOS adds a skill check in races, and there’s a lot of events for you to participate in. There’s also a much more larger library from cars to try out and exclusive MP customization’s. The payouts are also better than in SP, and making money is easy even for a complete beginner. 

The [b]story[/b] is actually decent for a driving game. Is those start from the bottom with a revenge plot, that makes you want to progress the game. However, it wasn’t very well delivered, and the writing is very weird and awkward at times, making some “GenZ” jokes, that don’t connect. There’s also events that don’t really make sense and a bad guy that never appears.

The [b]visuals[/b] are very good, and cars are extremely detailed and well done. They added a cartoonish art style to the game that was very controversial, however i think it gives a very distinct identity vs all other racing games, and they should continue in the future. The anime characters really contrast with the hyper realistic vehicles, which makes the car pop much more. Also, all the crazy effects just hype the driving (arrows popping when applying NOS, wings showing when doing jumps, etc).
Although the graphics are good, the atmosphere is disappointing. The whole game has a gray weather effect, that makes the game feel dull. Maybe it’s a design choice, to make the extremely colored visuals pop more. They also added NPC’s on the map to make the game feel more alive, which is a great touch.

The music, i can’t comment since it’s a very personal choice. The music leans more on rap music. However, the tone of the music is to much slow paced, even during races and cop chases, which, imo, is a downside.

About the [b]gameplay[/b], cars are now divided into different classes. You can make several builds for a car to enter different classes, which is interesting. Cars can only participate in the specific car class, which makes races more competitive. However, power-creep still exists, and 2 cars from the same class can still have huge differences in performance. You can finally do grip builds, unlike HEAT, and they are actually very satisfying to play. They added a complete new mechanic, burst NOS, which is separate from normal NOS and is gained by driving aggressively. Burst NOS gives a slight speed boost, but also increases your grip allowing to do corners with crazy angles. The idea behind it was good, but makes the races being decided by who can abuse the burst NOS better. The cops, overall, are a dumber version of HEAT, with the addition of us being able to damage them without damaging us, making them essentially not a threat. However, they are literally everywhere, and pop up every couple of seconds, while in a chase and just free-roaming.

The [b]customization[/b] is still one of the biggest points of NFS titles, and this is still present in UNBOUND, now with the added style effects. If you don’t like them, they offer you a way to remove those effects, but only for your car. For the player character, the customization is a lot more limiting and underwhelming.

About [b]SP[/b], was a complete downgrade from HEAT, and is one of the most boring experiences ever. Not only the progression is very slow, but it also seems to be designed to be time waster. Instead events being scattered all across the map, they are compressed to 6/7 meeting spots. All the safe-houses are far from most meeting spots, and you can’t TP. Also, races can be on the opposite side of the meeting spot, stopping you from being able to “combo” several races. You will waste more time driving from A to B to START a race, than actually racing. This is made worst by the fact that a cop shows every 30sec. You can either dodge it or risk to confront them and waste 10min evading them.  Also, the payouts are very low, so when you finish the game, if you just want to play around and experiment with new cars, you can, but you will have to grind A LOT. In terms of difficulty there is a difficulty wall in the beginning, but as soon as you pass it, the game just becomes increasingly easier, to the point where neither AI racers or cops can keep up with you. Also, SP wasn’t updated with any of the cars of the MP DLC’s.

About [b]MP[/b], the experience is much, much better than HEAT. Although UNBOUND has a lower player count, the player base is much more active, and much more willing to race, although very hardly you will find a full race lobby. The newcomer experience is much easier now, with a recent mode that allows you to get some cars for free, or sell them for big quantities, this without needing any upgraded car in your garage. There is also a free mode event, which a lot of people usually join in and participate. As expected, is much more common to find people playing in the higher classes. The car meta suffers a lot from power creep due to recent additions, so its very common to see always the same 2-3 cars. Sadly, they are so OP, that even driving well wont be enough if the adversary is using one of this cars. Finally, the payouts are also better, so if you wanna experiment with more cars, you should go to MP. Be warned that the SP garage isn’t shared with MP, like in HEAT, with the exception of those you won on special events and tournaments on SP.

About [b]performance[/b], i found a very big problem at the beginning of the game, where i couldn’t even pass from the first mission. After along time trying to troubleshoot, i found out that the issue was the FPS spike when loading cut scenes. Locking the FPS resolved my issues. However, i still encountered some crashes, mainly during SP. Also, this game has the same issue from HEAT, where your CPU is just pushed to 100%, constantly, for no reason. I recommend checking some videos on how to fix this, if you don’t want your PC smelling like a toaster.

[b]Need for Speed Unbound – A Bold, Stylish Evolution of Street Racing with Heart and Attitude[/b]

[i]Need for Speed Unbound[/i] brings the franchise roaring back with style, confidence, and a fresh identity that finally pushes the series forward. This isn’t just another NFS — it’s a celebration of underground racing culture, built with personality, attitude, and an artistic flair that makes every moment behind the wheel look and feel electric.

The first thing that hits you is the visual style. The combination of hyper-detailed cars and hand-drawn graffiti-inspired effects sounds risky on paper, but in practice it’s brilliant. Boost flames, wings drawn in paint strokes, comic-style sparks on drifts — these animations amplify the rush of speed rather than distract from it. Unbound looks unlike any racer out there, and that distinct identity becomes one of its greatest strengths.

Handling is tight, responsive, and exhilarating. Every car feels different — heavy muscle monsters, high-grip JDM legends, twitchy supercars — all brought to life with weight, power, and personality. Drifting and corner exits with perfectly timed boost feel incredible, rewarding skill instead of luck. For the first time in years, NFS racing feels truly competitive and satisfying, not just cinematic.

The risk vs. reward heat system is where excitement peaks. Every race earns money, but also raises police heat, and every night becomes a gamble — push your luck for bigger payouts or quit while you’re ahead. Evading cops through Lakeshore City’s alleys, highways, and industrial zones is a white-knuckle thrill that brings back the spirit of Most Wanted and Heat, but with even smarter police tactics and dramatic chases.

Progression is meaningful, not grindy. Your garage becomes your legacy — buying wrecks, upgrading engines, tuning setups, experimenting with parts, and designing bold liveries that match the game’s rebellious style. Every upgrade matters, and every dollar earned has purpose.

Story mode is another pleasant surprise. Voiced characters feel grounded in car culture rather than stereotypes, and the narrative of rivalry, betrayal, and ambition actually lands emotionally. Your character isn’t just a background driver — you’re part of the scene, and the journey to the top of Lakeshore’s racing hierarchy feels personal.

The soundtrack injects pure adrenaline — hip-hop, trap, and global underground beats match the tone and energy perfectly. It elevates every drift, jump, and police chase into a cinematic moment.

Multiplayer is slick and straightforward, built for seamless fun: fast matchmaking, competitive playlists, crew events, and the same fantastic car progression — without unnecessary grinding walls. It’s easy to lose hours simply cruising, racing, tuning, and flexing your style.

[i]Need for Speed Unbound[/i] is a bold new chapter — fast, stylish, confident, and unafraid to evolve. It respects the series’ roots but refuses to be stuck in the past. Story Mode: It's not a very good strongpoint for this title. I enjoyed playing single player once, never came back to it again. Multiplayer: At launch, it was a complete disaster. Basically, it was just a "free roam" like in Payback. EA tried to change it, made some progress here and there, but just like Heat, it was abandoned once again. They tried to make a NFS title that would have a live support. It doesn't really work with NFS titles. Simply, it would be something like "a Forza Horizon clone" if you get me (no hate towards Forza, but i think we can all agree that we are sick of these street racing games, that don't even represent street racing properly).


Customization: This is a pretty good strongpoint for Unbound. I liked some of the customization and aftermarket parts that were available. Hell, you can even remove bumpers this time ! Customization is pretty okay, but nothing THAT special... except they tried to make something special. You see, i don't hate these effects when you either, go flying or use burst nitrous because at the end of the day, NFS is an arcade racing game. Artstyle: Not a big fan of the cartoon artstyle. I won't criticise it that much because i don't really understand the whole art thing. I guess it's okay to see, that they tried something new ? 


Microtranscations: Guys, it's EA. Of course they will implement an offer into every possible corner visible. Expensive, irrelevant, uninteresting. Simply, not worth it. 


DLC'S: Pretty much the same case like microtransactions. Expensive and lazy content.


Dear Electronic Arts,
If you want to make a street racing game, AND if you want to actually succeed making a good title, then please, take Need for Speed Unbound as a good reason of what NOT to do as a representation of a street racing game. This franchise could not have possibly gone in a worse direction. Aside from the graphics, nearly EVERYTHING is a downgrade over Heat.

• Soundtrack: There are probably a couple of songs that fit the theme of a racing game; the rest are either forgettable or straight-up slop with no effort put into them.

• Story: Mediocre at best, irritating at worst.

• Car sounds: A muffled & quieter version of Heat’s.

• Cop presence/AI behaviour: Less aggressive, dumber, and slower than in Heat while also being painfully difficult to get around them at high heat levels because they spawn LITERALLY EVERYWHERE WITH HELICOPTERS. The cop sighting system is pretty cool, though.

• Singleplayer campaign structure/replayability: The week system could work in theory, but it falls flat on its face with its execution as it basically allows you to skip certain days without any downsides. Also, I REALLY dislike the fact that you can only choose from events that are available on certain days instead of all of them being available at once. It doesn't even show which events you've already completed.

• Difficulty/racing AI behaviour: Utterly unbalanced, especially in S+ events because none of your opponents' cars are properly upgraded to keep up with you, even though they're actually capable of driving well.

• Handling physics: Somehow nearly as bad as NFS 2015's physics. Drifting is essentially a death sentence because the ability to countersteer is practically nonexistent. Gripping through corners doesn't feel great either because it feels like you're driving on rails with the random chance of spinning out with no control over it. Certain cars cannot go through bumps without frantically bouncing and often going airborne. To top all that off, most cars can also feel weirdly snappy, even on the lowest steering sensitivity setting.

• DLC/monetisation/content updates: What the actual f**k. A large chunk of all the paid DLC content is multiplayer-focused in a battlepass-like system which were initially sold for atrocious prices. And of course, the singeplayer mode got none of the new cool gamemodes, other than the mostly underwhelming cars.

Can absolutely recommend... avoiding this one, unless it's on a 90% sale and you want to mod the living hell out of it.
